page.title: 16THE RENFREW FERRY
page.content: Renfrew, on the banks of the River Clyde, was first granted a 'right of ferry' by Robert lll in the 14th century and there has certainly been a ferry since 1710. In 1984 however the old chain driven ferry was replaced by two new motor ferries called the "Renfrew Rose" and the "Yoker Swan" after its ports of call.The names were chosen by local children. In 1984 the ferry carried about 200 cars and 800 people a day. However this level of traffic is a marked deterioration on the days before the Clyde Tunnel, Erskine Bridge and the motorway so that the old ferry was no longer viable. Thus in July 1984 fares rose by 25% and the two 60ft motor launches took over, signalling the demise of the last chain driven ferry on the Clyde and nostalgic names like "Number One".
